Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[TFM Display] Badges and Table UI." (#8885) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Description
- HTML partials added for badges and table components for `DisplayPackagePageV2`.
- TFM feature flag and flight added.
- `PackageFrameworkCompatibilityFactory` now returns an immutable dictionary with the first four keys ordered to be .NET the based frameworks (if they have compatible frameworks for the package), the remaining keys are ordered by alphabetical order.
- `GetBadgeVersion()` extension method returns the version that we are going to display for the .NET badge framework.
- Checked accessibility (needed to change color due to contrast a11y issue).

## Addresses
- https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3911
- https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3956

## Screenshots

<details>
<summary>Package with supported frameworks, table and badges shown in UI</summary>

![Iteration 3 - Package with table and badges](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149223063-3375b42f-04b3-48de-b021-3777ca90de30.png)

</details>
<details>
<summary>Package with supported frameworks, but not .NET framework in asset.</summary>
NOTE: On badges we only show a .NET based framework if it's in the assets.

![Iteration 3 - Package with table and no badges, with net computed framework](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149223135-a58a1da6-e7ea-42f7-a075-4843a5f29238.png)

</details>
<details>
<summary>Package with no supported frameworks in their assets.</summary>

NOTE: Badges are not shown here, and since there are no supported assets we provide a little message.
![Iteration 3 - No supported frameworks, no table nor badges](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149562427-383b6edf-f0e6-419a-9f71-3c9a8d4dc760.png)

</details>
<details>

<summary>Newtonsoft.json before removing deprecated/unofficial frameworks</summary>

![Iteration 2 - Newtonsoft](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/148852915-91c8d52e-38ea-4d6f-a5e6-2c10e412df0c.png)

</details>
<details>
<summary>Newtonsoft.json after removing deprecated/unofficial frameworks</summary>

![Iteration 3 - Newtonsoft](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149223350-b6be4059-16f1-4c55-8f1f-2ed4fdb74840.png)

</details>
<details>
<summary>Package with only netstandard1.0</summary>

![Iteration 3 - Package only netstandard1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149224049-1f6b4d93-90bf-4ce4-8e7f-922bb60ac314.png)

</details>
<details>
<summary>Package with net5.0-windows10.0.17763</summary>

![Iteration 3 - net5 specific windows version](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149213822-33b1c08b-12c4-4cc8-801b-24d84d97f335.png)

</details>
<details>
<summary>Package with only net5/6 windows10.0.18362</summary>

![Iteration 3 - only net5 and 6 specific windows versions](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/149214028-7caafc95-a88d-4697-aa94-73edead6d9bb.png)

</details>

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Cannot install upgrade assistant [Bug]: " (#11514) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

dotnet tool install -g upgrade-assistant

### Worked before?

Not sure

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

1 install .NET 6
2 RUN 'dotnet tool install -g upgrade-assistant' in cmd

### Verbose Logs

```shell
error NU3008: Package 'upgrade-assistant 0.3.261602' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The package integrity check failed. The package has changed since it was signed. Try clearing the local http-cache and run nuget operation again.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: NuGet.Client TopologicalSortUtility Retrieves Dependencies From Wrong Location" (#11513) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet SDK

### Product Version

NuGet.ProjectModel 6.0.0

### Worked before?

don't know

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

- NuGet.ProjectModel.DependencyGraphSpec provides static method SortPackagesByDependencyOrder
- this in turn uses NuGet.Packaging.TopologicalSortUtility
- method CalculateRelationships retrieves a package's dependencies via PackageInfo.Package.Dependencies (line 69)
- but these top-level dependencies are always empty, since dependencies are located at each target framework
- see, e.g., [https://www.jerriepelser.com/blog/analyze-dotnet-project-dependencies-part-1/](url)
- so, instead, dependencies should be collected from each target framework (see link)
- the current behaviour leads the topolocial sort utility to believe that no package has any dependencies at all, resulting in a complete arbitrary package order (which is not sorted by dependency order at all)

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PackageDownload: support GeneratePathProperty" (#11510) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If my understand is correct, `PackageDownload` items currently don't support `GeneratePathProperty`. This loses a lot of potential value prop because in the scenarios where you use `PackageDownload` you're highly likely to want to know a deterministic path to the package contents where it was laid out on disk.

Right now the only way we can see is rely on `$(NuGetPackageRoot)` which is problematic because I've seen users remap it to say E:\NuGet (without the trailing slash), wreaking all sorts of havoc.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageDownload: support GeneratePathProperty" (#11510) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If my understand is correct, `PackageDownload` items currently don't support `GeneratePathProperty`. This loses a lot of potential value prop because in the scenarios where you use `PackageDownload` you're highly likely to want to know a deterministic path to the package contents where it was laid out on disk.

Right now the only way we can see is rely on `$(NuGetPackageRoot)` which is problematic because I've seen users remap it to say E:\NuGet (without the trailing slash), wreaking all sorts of havoc.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Linux machines failing CI builds due to dotnet-install connection problem" (#8936) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Linux Machines are failing to run Functional Tests when attempting to run dotnet-install.sh.
There appears to be some network configuration or connectivity problem.
`curl: (7) Failed to connect to dotnet.microsoft.com port 443: Connection timed out`

Example failing builds:
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3298450
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3298446
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3298399

As a temporary workaround, I placed the resolved script directly into our build folder: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8931

[This build](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3317306) calls  curl -o cli/dotnet-install.sh -L -v https://dot.net/v1/dotnet-install.sh.  curl follows a redirection to https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/scripts/v1/dotnet-install.sh but is then unable to reach that URL.

@dtivel  noticed that curl tries using the IPv6 address, so he forced IPv4 in [this build](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3317526), but the overall failure is still the same.
Adding detailed design notes for transitive dependencies

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve error message for dotnet add package NuGet.Versioning fails for Repository trusted signers" (#11509) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Let's say nuget.config contains below:
```
  <trustedSigners>
    <repository name="NuGetTrust" serviceIndex="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json">
      <certificate fingerprint="0e5f38f57dc1bcc806d8494f4f90fbcedd988b46760709cbeec6f4219aa6157d" hashAlgorithm="SHA256" allowUntrustedRoot="false" />

      <owners>test</owners>
    </repository>
  </trustedSigners>
```


**dotnet add package nuget.versioning fails, error message is not clear exact what failed**

```

info : Package 'NuGet.Versioning 6.0.0' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json':   Issued by: CN=DigiCert SHA2 Assured ID Code Signing CA, OU=www.digicert.com, O=DigiCert Inc, C=US
log  : Package 'NuGet.Versioning 6.0.0' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json':   Valid from: 9/29/2020 5:00:00 PM to 10/5/2023 5:00:00 AM

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "LocalPackageFileCache provides no extension point for users to improve its performance " (#10325) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (any):

NuGet version (any):

dotnet.exe --version (any):

VS version (any):

OS version (any):

Worked before? never

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

We are using NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand to restore nuget packages and store them on Azure Storage.

Unfortunately LocalPackageFileCache is very slow and in order to optimize it we need to extend it. Unfortunately the class does not implement any interface nor has virtual methods.

Set fallback folders and install path to a disk with slow access. Restoring from it will be slow even if all packages are cached because LocalPackageFileCache try to access the actual files. Still in specific user scenario checking for the actual disk files may be avoid and performance may be improved.

## Other suggested things

Making LocalPackageFileCache methods virtual would be the minimum requirement to give NuGet clients an extension point for optimizations.

### Verbose Logs

Not applicable

### Sample Project

Not applicable

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add TFM for .NET nanoFramework" (#10800) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
TFM Component  | Value
---------------|------------------
Friendly name  | netnano
TFI            | .NETnanoFramework

### Goals

* NuGet needs to able to recognize the TFM for .NET nanoFramework and select assets from a NuGet package into a project that targets .NET nanoFramework.
* NuGet needs to allow creating a NuGet package that includes assets for .NET nanoFramework.
* Normal versioning rules need to apply (e.g. a package can offer assets for multiple versions of the .NET nanoFramework and NuGet will use the largest version that is less or equal to the targeted version).
* Once NuGet knows of the TFM for .NET nanoFramework, the .NET nanoFramework maintainers should be able to ship new versions without having to submit any changes to the NuGet client.

### Non-Goals

* NuGet doesn't need to understand any compatibility relationships between .NET nanoFramework and other TFM.

The spec is [here](https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/208)
